intro: Paronychia kapela subsp. serpyllifolia, commonly known as creeping thistle or common mouse-ear, is a perennial herbaceous plant native to temperate regions of Europe and Asia. It belongs to the family Asteraceae, characterized by its composite flower heads and alternate leaves. The plant typically grows in grasslands, meadows, and disturbed soils, forming dense mats due to its stolons. Its leaves are generally hairy, with a spoon-shaped base, and it produces small yellow flowers in clusters. It is often used in traditional medicine and has ornamental value in gardens.
